q: What is 'API Integration'?
o: The process of connecting two or more applications or systems via their APIs to exchange data and perform actions

q: What does API stand for?
Which is the most common architectural style for modern web APIs?
What data format is most commonly used with REST APIs?
What is an 'Endpoint' in the context of an API?
o: A specific URL where an API can be accessed to perform a specific function
The end of the code file

q: Which HTTP method is typically used to retrieve data?
Which HTTP method is typically used to create a new resource?
Which HTTP method is typically used to update an existing resource completely?
Which HTTP method is typically used to delete a resource?
What does a 200 OK status code mean?
What does a 404 Not Found status code mean?
o: The requested resource could not be found

q: What does a 500 Internal Server Error status code mean?
o: The server encountered an unexpected condition that prevented it from fulfilling the request
The user is not logged in

q: What is a 'Payload' or 'Body' in an API request?
o: Data sent by the client to the server (e.g., in POST or PUT requests) containing details for the operation

q: What is an 'API Key'?
o: A unique identifier used to authenticate a user, developer, or calling program to an API
A key to open the server room

q: What is 'Basic Authentication'?
o: A simple method where the username and password are encoded in Base64 and sent in the Authorization header

q: What is the primary difference between HTTP and HTTPS?
o: HTTPS is secure (Encrypted using TLS/SSL), whereas HTTP sends data in plain text

q: What tool is widely used for manually testing APIs?
What command-line tool is commonly used to make HTTP requests?
What is 'Swagger' or 'OpenAPI'?
o: A specification and set of tools for defining and documenting RESTful APIs

q: What is a 'Query Parameter'?
o: A key-value pair added to the end of a URL after a '?' to filter or modify the request

q: In the URL `http://api.example.com/users?id=123`, what is `id=123`?
What is specific about SOAP APIs?
o: They strictly use XML for message format and typically run over HTTP or SMTP

q: What is WSDL?
o: Web Services Description Language, an XML-based file used to describe SOAP services

q: What does 'CRUD' stand for?
What is the 'Authorization' header used for?
o: To send credentials (tokens, keys) to verify the client's identity and permissions
To tell the server what file type to return

q: What is 'Rate Limiting'?
o: Restricting the number of requests a client can make to an API within a specific time frame

q: What HTTP status code is usually returned when Rate Limit is exceeded?
What is 'API Documentation' important for?
o: Helping developers understand how to use the API, what endpoints exist, and what the request/response formats are

q: What is a 'Base URL'?
o: The common root part of the URL for all endpoints in an API (e.g., https://api.example.com/v1)

q: What is the difference between URI and URL?
o: URI (Identifier) is the superset; URL (Locator) is a specific type of URI that includes access mechanism (e.g. http://)
URL is for text, URI is for images

q: What is 'Content-Type' header?
o: Indicates the media type of the resource (e.g., application/json) sent in the body

q: What is 'Accept' header?
o: Tells the server what content types the client is able to understand/accept in the response
Tells the server to accept the connection
Tells the server to accept cookies

q: What is a 201 Created status code?
o: The request has typically been fulfilled and has resulted in a new resource being created
The request was received but not processed

q: What is a 400 Bad Request status code?
o: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed syntax)

q: Which of these is a valid JSON object?
What is 'Latency' in API context?
o: The time it takes for a request to travel from client to server and back

q: What is 'Versioning' in APIs?
o: Managing changes to the API over time (e.g., /v1/, /v2/) so that existing clients generally don't break

q: What is a 401 Unauthorized status code?
o: The request has not been applied because it lacks valid authentication credentials

q: What is a 403 Forbidden status code?
o: The server understood the request but refuses to authorize it (client is authenticated but has no permission)

q: What is the purpose of 'Environment Variables' in API testing?
o: To store values like base URLs or tokens that change between environments (Dev, Test, Prod) without changing code

q: What is a 'Collection' in Postman?
o: A group of saved API requests

q: What is 'GraphQL'?
o: A query language for APIs that allows clients to ask for exactly the data they need

q: What is the main advantage of GraphQL over REST?
o: Avoids over-fetching and under-fetching of data

q: What does a 204 No Content status code mean?
o: The server successfully processed the request and is not returning any content

q: Is GET request idempotent?
o: Yes, making multiple identical requests has the same effect as making a single request (no side effects)

q: Is POST request idempotent?
o: No, multiple identical POST requests will likely create multiple resources or trigger multiple actions

q: What is the 'User-Agent' header?
o: Identifies the application, operating system, vendor, and / or version of the requesting user agent (client)

q: What is 'Polling'?
o: Repeatedly sending requests to an endpoint to check for updates or new data

q: What is a 'Webhook'?
o: A mechanism where the server sends a request to the client (inverse API) when an event occurs

q: What is typical format for a Date in JSON APIs?

What is the key structural difference between SOAP and REST messages?
o: SOAP messages must be XML wrapped in an Envelope (Header/Body); REST messages can be any format (JSON/XML/Text) and don't strictly require an envelope
SOAP uses JSON, REST uses XML

q: What is 'HATEOAS' in REST?
o: Hypermedia As The Engine Of Application State; the API response includes links to related resources, guiding the client on what it can do next

q: In the Richardson Maturity Model, what is Level 0?
o: The Swamp of POX (Plain Old XML); using HTTP as a transport tunnel for remote procedure calls (RPC), typically with a single endpoint

q: In Richardson Maturity Model, what is Level 2?
o: Using HTTP verbs (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) and status codes correctly for different operations on resources

q: What is the main semantic difference between PUT and PATCH?
o: PUT replaces the entire resource (if fields are missing, they are cleared); PATCH applies a partial update (only changing fields sent)

q: Which HTTP method is defined as 'Safe' (should not change state on server)?
What is the purpose of the 'Cache-Control' header?
o: To tell the browser or intermediate caches how long to store the response and when to re-validate it

q: What is an 'ETag'?
o: An identifier (hash/version) for a specific version of a resource, used for conditional requests and caching

q: How does 'If-None-Match' header work with ETag?
o: Client sends the ETag it has; if Server's current ETag matches, it returns 304 Not Modified (saving bandwidth); otherwise 200 with new data

q: What is 'CORS' (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)?
o: A browser security feature that restricts web pages from making requests to a different domain than the one that served the web page, unless allowed by headers

q: Which header does the server send to allow CORS requests from any domain?
What is 'Offset-based' pagination?
o: Client asks for `limit` items and `offset` (skip) number of items (e.g. limit=10, offset=20)

q: What is a disadvantage of Offset-based pagination?
o: Performance degrades with large offsets (database must scan and skip rows), and data drift can cause missed/duplicate items if rows are added/deleted

q: What is 'Cursor-based' pagination?
o: Client provides a pointer (cursor) from the last item received (e.g. `after_id=105`), allowing efficient fetching of the next set

q: What is an 'API Gateway'?
o: A server that acts as an API front-end, receiving API requests, enforcing throttling and security policies, passing requests to the back-end service, and then passing the response back to the requester

q: What is 'JSON Schema'?
o: A vocabulary that allows you to annotate and validate JSON documents (defining required fields, types, formats)

q: What is XML 'xmlns' attribute used for?
o: Defining an XML Namespace to avoid element name conflicts when mixing vocabularies

q: In SOAP, where are the parameters for the operation typically located?
What is 'Content Negotiation'?
o: The mechanism used for serving different representations of a resource at the same URI, so that the user agent can specify which is best suited for the user (using Accept headers)

q: What is a 405 Method Not Allowed error?
o: The request method is known by the server but is not supported by the target resource (e.g. POST on a read-only endpoint)

q: What is a 415 Unsupported Media Type error?
o: The server refuses to accept the request because the payload format is in an unsupported format (e.g. XML sent, but JSON expected)

q: What is 'Idempotency Key' pattern?
o: A header sent by client (e.g. `Idempotency-Key: uuid`) so the server can recognize retries of the same operation (like payment) and process it only once

q: In REST, resources are typically identified by?
What is 'RPC' (Remote Procedure Call) style?
o: Action-oriented usage of API where endpoints are named after functions (e.g. /deleteUser, /calculateTax) rather than resources

q: What does 'Stateless' mean in REST?
o: Each request from client to server must contain all of the information necessary to understand the request, and cannot take advantage of any stored context on the server (like sessions)
The server is in a specific country

q: What is a 'Leaky Bucket' algorithm used for?
o: Rate limiting; requests enter the bucket at irregular rates but leak out (are processed) at a constant rate

q: What is a 301 Moved Permanently?
o: The requested resource has been assigned a new permanent URI and future references should use one of the returned URIs

q: What is a 302 Found (Temporary Redirect)?
o: The resource resides temporarily under a different URI

q: What is a 'Preflight Request' in CORS?
o: An OPTIONS request sent by the browser before the actual request to check if the server allows the method and headers

q: How do you specify multiple values for a query parameter conventionally?
o: `?id=1&id=2` or `?id=1,2` or `?id[]=1&id[]=2` (depends on API framework support)

q: What is 'URL Encoding' (Percent Encoding)?
o: Mechanism for encoding information in a URI where restricted characters are replaced by % followed by two hexadecimal digits (e.g. space becomes %20)

q: What is the standard port for HTTPS?
What is the standard port for HTTP?
What is the header `X-Forwarded-For` used for?
o: To identify the originating IP address of a client connecting to a web server through an HTTP proxy or load balancer

q: What is 'Token Bucket' algorithm?
o: Rate limiting; tokens are added to bucket at fixed rate. A request consumes a token. If empty, request is rejected. Allows bursts.

q: What represents 'Null' in JSON?
Can JSON contain comments?
o: No, standard JSON does not support comments

q: What is 'gRPC'?
o: A modern open source high performance Remote Procedure Call (RPC) framework that can run in any environment, typically using Protobuf

q: What is 'Protobuf' (Protocol Buffers)?
o: A language-neutral, platform-neutral extensible mechanism for serializing structured data (binary format), usually smaller and faster than XML/JSON

q: What is 'Throttling' vs 'Rate Limiting'?
o: Often used efficiently; Throttling might slow down requests (queue/delay), Rate Limiting hard rejects them after a limit. Or used purely as synonyms.

What is the 'Backends for Frontends' (BFF) pattern?
o: Creating separate backend services to be consumed by specific frontends (e.g. one for Mobile, one for Web) to optimize data for that client

q: What is a 'Circuit Breaker' in API integration?
o: A design pattern that detects failures and prevents the application from trying to execute an operation that is likely to fail (giving the failing service time to recover)
A method to break the code

q: What is 'Exponential Backoff'?
o: A retry strategy where the wait time between retries increases exponentially (e.g., 1s, 2s, 4s, 8s) to reduce load on a failing service

q: What is 'Service Mesh'?
o: An infrastructure layer (often using sidecars) for handling service-to-service communication, monitoring, and security in microservices

q: What is the 'Sidecar' pattern?
o: Deploying a helper component (process/container) alongside the main application container to handle auxiliary tasks like logging or proxying

q: What is 'Bulkhead' pattern?
o: Isolating elements of an application into pools so that if one fails, the others continue to function (preventing cascading failures)

q: What is the main difference between WebSockets and Server-Sent Events (SSE)?
o: WebSockets provide full-duplex (two-way) communication; SSE provides simplex (one-way, server-to-client) communication

q: What is a key benefit of HTTP/2 over HTTP/1.1?
o: Multiplexing (sending multiple requests and responses in parallel over a single TCP connection)

q: What is 'Header Compression' in HTTP/2?
o: HPACK compression reduces overhead by compressing header fields, which is efficient since headers often repeat (User-Agent, Cookies)

q: What is 'OAuth2'?
o: An industry-standard protocol for authorization (delegated access)

q: What is 'OpenID Connect' (OIDC)?
o: An identity layer on top of OAuth 2.0 used for Authentication (verifying who the user is)

q: What are the three parts of a JWT (JSON Web Token)?
Where is the 'Client Credentials' flow typically used in OAuth2?
o: Machine-to-machine communication where no user is present

q: What is the 'Authorization Code' flow best for?
o: Server-side web applications where the source code is not publicly exposed and can keep the client secret confidential

q: What is 'API Mocking'?
o: Simulating the behavior of a real API (responses, delays, errors) to allow development/testing in isolation

q: What is 'Contract Testing'?
o: Testing to ensure that services (Consumer and Provider) adhere to a shared agreement (contract) regarding message formats

q: What is a 'Breaking Change' in an API?
o: A change that causes existing clients to fail (e.g., removing a field, renaming an endpoint)

q: What is 'Semantic Versioning' (SemVer)?
o: Versioning convention X.Y.Z (Major.Minor.Patch) where Major indicates breaking changes

q: What is 'Header Versioning'?
o: Specifying the API version in a custom header (e.g. `Accept-Version: v1`) rather than the URL

q: What is 'AsyncAPI' specification?
o: A specification (like OpenAPI) but for defining asynchronous, event-driven APIs (e.g. Kafka, RabbitMQ, WebSockets)

q: What distinguishes 'Event-Driven Architecture'?
o: Components communicate by producing and consuming events (messages associated with changes in state) usually asynchronously

q: What is 'Jitter' in retry mechanism?
o: Adding random variation to the wait time in retries to prevent 'thundering herd' problem (all clients retrying at exact same moment)

q: What is 'Mutual TLS' (mTLS)?
o: Two-way authentication where both client and server verify each other's certificates

q: What is a 'Reverse Proxy'?
o: A server that sits in front of one or more web servers, intercepting requests from clients and forwarding them to the appropriate server

q: What is 'Load Balancing'?
o: Distributing network traffic across multiple servers to ensure no single server bears too much load

q: What is 'Sticky Session' (Session Affinity) in Load Balancing?
o: Routing all requests from a specific client to the same server backend for the duration of the session

q: What is 'Chaos Engineering'?
o: Discipline of experimenting on a system (e.g., shutting down servers randomly) to build confidence in its capability to withstand turbulent conditions

q: What is an 'API Marketplace'?
o: A platform where API providers publish APIs and developers find and subscribe to them (e.g., RapidAPI)

q: What is 'Webhook Security' best practice?
o: Verifying the signature (HMAC) of the payload to ensure it came from the expected sender

q: What is 'Field Level Security'?
o: Restricting access to specific fields within a resource based on user permissions

q: What is the 'Discoverability' constraint in REST?
o: Service definition and resources should be discoverable (often via HATEOAS or a service registry)

q: What is 'N+1 Problem' in API fetching?
o: Fetching a list of N items, then making an additional query for each item to get related data (1 + N queries), causing performance issues

q: How does GraphQL solve N+1 problem?
o: By allowing nested queries in a single request, and backend optimizing resolution (e.g. DataLoader pattern)

q: What is 'Over-fetching'?
o: Downloading more data than is actually used by the app (common in fixed-structure REST endpoints)

q: What is 'Under-fetching'?
o: Downloading insufficient data from an endpoint, requiring additional requests to get everything needed

q: What is a 'Dead Letter Queue' (DLQ)?
o: A queue where messages that cannot be processed (after retries) are sent for analysis, rather than being lost

q: What is 'API Governance'?
o: Policies and standards applied to API development to ensure consistency, security, and compliance across an organization

q: What is 'Schema Evolution'?
o: The process of modifying the structure of data (schema) while maintaining backward compatibility

q: What is 'Polyglot Persistence'?
o: Using different data storage technologies (SQL, NoSQL, Cache) to handle different data storage needs within the same application

q: What is 'Saga Pattern'?
o: A sequence of local transactions where each transaction updates data within a single service, coordinating long-running distributed transactions

q: What is 'Compensating Transaction' in Saga?
o: A transaction that undoes the changes made by a previous transaction if a subsequent step fails

q: What is 'API monetization'?
o: Strategies to generate revenue from APIs (e.g. subscriptions, pay-per-call, freemium)

q: What is 'Developer Portal'?
o: A website hosting API documentation, credentials management, and support for developers consuming your API

What is 'OData' (Open Data Protocol)?
o: An ISO/IEC approved standard that defines a set of best practices for building and consuming queryable RESTful APIs (e.g. $filter, $select)

q: What is 'JSON-RPC'?
o: A stateless, light-weight remote procedure call (RPC) protocol encoded in JSON, typically using a single endpoint

q: What is a 'SOAP Fault'?
o: A standard structure in a SOAP message body used to report errors (containing FaultCode, FaultString, Detail)

q: What is the 'Link' header in REST used for?
o: To provide links to related resources (e.g., for pagination 'next'/'prev', or HATEOAS) without modifying the response body

q: What is 'SSRF' (Server-Side Request Forgery)?
o: A vulnerability where an attacker induces the server-side application to make HTTP requests to an arbitrary domain of the attacker's choosing

q: What is 'Mass Assignment' vulnerability?
o: Binding HTTP request parameters directly to code variables or database objects allows attackers to modify fields they shouldn't (e.g. `isAdmin=true`)

q: What is 'BOLA' (Broken Object Level Authorization) or IDOR?
o: Attacker accesses objects (e.g. /users/123) that they shouldn't have access to, by simply guessing or changing the ID, because authorization checks are missing

q: What is 'Sliding Window Log' rate limiting?
o: Keeps a log of timestamps for each request. When a new request comes, remove timestamps older than the window. If count > limit, reject. very accurate but expensive RAM.

q: What is 'Sliding Window Counter' rate limiting?
o: Hybrid approach; accounts for the weighted value of the previous window's request count + current window's count to approximate sliding rate with low memory usage

q: What is 'Media Type Versioning' (Vendor Extensions)?
o: Requesting a specific version via the Accept header using a custom MIME type (e.g. `application/vnd.myapi.v1+json`)

q: What is 's-maxage' in Cache-Control?
o: Like max-age, but strictly for shared caches (e.g., CDNs, proxies). Browsers ignore it.

q: What is 'stale-while-revalidate' directive?
o: Tells cache: 'Serve the stale content immediately (fast), but asynchronously trigger a revalidation request to the server to update the cache for next time'

q: What is the difference between Service Discovery 'Client-side' vs 'Server-side'?
o: Client-side: Client queries Service Registry to get IP of service, then calls it. Server-side: Client calls a Load Balancer (Router), which queries Registry and forwards.

q: What is 'Distributed Tracing'?
o: Tracking the flow of a request across multiple microservices/boundaries using a unique Trace ID passed in headers (like `traceparent`)

q: What is 'OpenTelemetry'?
o: An observability framework and toolkit designed to create and manage telemetry data such as traces, metrics, and logs

q: Is 'Long Polling' better than 'Polling'?
o: Yes, client opens connection, server holds it open until new data is available (or timeout). Reduces empty checks compared to standard polling.

q: In GraphQL, what is 'Schema Federation'?
o: Combining multiple subgraphs (distinct schemas from different services) into a single supergraph (gateway) that clients query

q: What are 'Directives' in GraphQL (e.g. @include)?
o: Instructions decorating part of a GraphQL document (query/schema) to alter execution behavior (e.g. conditionally including a field)

q: What is a gRPC 'Interceptor'?
o: Middleware that intercepts execution of gRPC calls on client or server side (for logging, auth, etc.)

q: What does gRPC status 'DEADLINE_EXCEEDED' mean?
What is 'Content-Disposition' header used for in APIs?
o: To indicate if the content is expected to be displayed inline or as an attachment (download file), and optionally the filename

q: What is 'API Orchestration' vs 'Choreography'?
o: Orchestration: Central controller (conductor) tells services what to do. Choreography: Services react to events/messages independently (dancers) without central control.

q: What is a 'BFF' specifically solving?
o: Prevents 'Over-fetching' for mobile, manages specific auth needs, and aggregates data relevant to a specific user experience

q: What is 'Shadow Traffic' (Mirroring)?
o: Replaying real production traffic against a new version of the service (in a dark/shadow mode) to test it without affecting real users

q: What is 'Canary Release'?
o: Rolling out a change to a small subset of users (canaries) first to detect issues before full rollout

q: What is 'Blue-Green Deployment'?
o: Two identical environments (Blue=Live, Green=Idle). Deploy to Green, test, then switch router to Green. Instant rollback possible.

q: What is 'Reference Token' vs 'Value Token' (JWT)?
o: Value Token (JWT) contains all data/claims (self-contained). Reference Token is just an ID pointing to data stored on auth server (requires lookup).

q: What is 'PKCE' (Proof Key for Code Exchange) in OAuth?
o: Security extension for public clients (mobile/SPA) to prevent authorization code interception attacks

q: What is 'API Throttling' typically based on?
o: Slowing down requests (adding latency) rather than just rejecting them, or rejecting based on tier

q: What is 'Claim-Check Pattern'?
o: Send a large message payload to storage (blob), and send only the reference (check) in the message bus to keep messages small

q: What is 'Ambassador Pattern'?
o: A helper service that sends network requests on behalf of a consumer service or application (handling retry, circuit breaking, monitoring)

q: What is 'Strangler Fig Pattern'?
o: Gradually migrating a legacy system by replacing specific pieces of functionality with new microservices until the legacy system is strangled (gone)

q: What is 'CQRS' (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)?
o: Separating read and write operations for a data store model (often effectively using different models/DBs for read vs write)

q: What is 'Event Sourcing'?
o: Storing the state of a system as a sequence of events (immutable log) rather than just current state. State is derived by replaying events.

q: What is 'CAP Theorem' relevant for?
o: Distributed Data Stores: Consistency, Availability, Partition Tolerance. You can pick only two.

q: What represents '12-Factor App' config principle?

What is 'Sunset' header used for?
o: Communicating the date and time when a deprecated API endpoint will become unresponsive

q: What is 'Partial Failure' in a Bulk API?
o: When a request to process multiple items results in some succeeding and some failing (e.g. 207 Multi-Status)

q: What does a 207 Multi-Status response body typically contain?
o: An array of status codes and bodies for each individual operation in the bulk request

q: Why use 'Brotli' compression over 'Gzip' for APIs?
o: Brotli offers better compression ratios (smaller payloads) for text-based formats like JSON/HTML, though it might be slightly slower to compress

q: What is the purpose of 'Heartbeat' or 'Ping/Pong' frames in functionality?
o: To keep the connection alive (prevent timeouts by load balancers) and detect if the other side has disconnected silently

q: What is 'Latency' vs 'Throughput'?
o: Latency is time for one request (speed); Throughput is number of requests per second (capacity)
Latency is size, Throughput is speed
Latency is errors, Throughput is success

q: What is 'p99 Latency'?
o: The latency value below which 99% of requests fall (meaning only the slowest 1% are worse). A better metric than average for tail performance.

q: What is 'Offline-First' API design?
o: Designing apps to work without network, queuing mutations locally, and syncing (eventual consistency) when network returns

q: What is 'Injection Attack' via API parameters?
o: Inserting malicious code (SQL, NoSQL, OS command) into input parameters that is then executed by the backend

q: What is 'PII' redaction in API logs?
o: Masking or removing Personally Identifiable Information (emails, phones, credit cards) from logs to comply with privacy laws

q: What is 'GDPR' Right to Erasure (Right to be Forgotten)?
o: The requirement to delete all personal data of a user upon request (including from backups and logs)

q: What is 'Data Residency' requirement?
o: Legal requirement that data about a nation's citizens must be stored on servers physically located within that nation

q: What is 'Smoke Testing' an API?
o: Running a minimal set of tests on critical paths (e.g. login, get user) to ensure the deployment isn't broken before deep testing

q: What is 'Synthetic Monitoring'?
o: Simulating user traffic/API calls at regular intervals from different locations to monitor uptime and performance

q: What is 'Race Condition' in APIs?
o: When software behavior depends on the timing of uncontrollable events (e.g. two concurrent requests modifying same data leading to corruption)

q: How to prevent Race Conditions in DB updates via API?
o: Use transactions with appropriate isolation levels, or Optimistic Locking (versioning)

q: What is 'Optimistic Locking'?
o: Read a record version; when updating, check if version is still the same. If not, fail (data changed by someone else).

q: What is 'Pessimistic Locking'?
o: Locking the record in the database when reading it for update, preventing others from reading/updating until transaction is done

q: What is 'Webhook Retries' best practice from Provider side?
o: Retry with exponential backoff if the receiver returns 5xx or fails to connect. Give up after N tries.

q: What is 'Canonical URL'?
o: The preferred URL for a resource, used to avoid duplicate content issues in SEO and caching

q: What is 'API Sandbox'?
o: An isolated environment duplicating production functionality but using test data, allowing developers to experiment safely

q: What is 'Rate Limit Evasion'?
o: Attacker rotates IP addresses or API keys to bypass rate limits

q: What is 'Credential Stuffing'?
o: Automated injection of breached username/password pairs in order to fraudulently gain access to user accounts

q: What is 'Certificate Pinning'?
o: Hardcoding the expected server certificate (or public key) in the client app to prevent Man-in-the-Middle attacks leveraging compromised CAs

q: What is 'HSTS' (HTTP Strict Transport Security)?
o: Response header telling browsers to ONLY access the site via HTTPS for a specified period (preventing downgrade attacks)

q: What is 'API Fuzzing'?
o: Automated software testing technique that provides invalid, unexpected, or random data as inputs to find bugs/crashes

q: What is 'Logic Bomb'?
o: Malicious code inserted into a network causing it to perform an action (like crash) only when certain conditions are met

q: What is 'Zero Trust' architecture?
o: Security model that assumes no user or device is trustworthy (even inside the network perimeter) and requires verification for every request

q: What is difference between 'Authentication' and 'Authorization'?
o: Authentication verifies WHO you are (Identity). Authorization verifies WHAT you can do (Permissions).

q: What is 'Role-Based Access Control' (RBAC)?
o: Restricting system access to authorized users based on their role (e.g. Admin, Editor, Viewer)

q: What is 'Attribute-Based Access Control' (ABAC)?
o: Access rights are granted to users through the use of policies which combine attributes together (User attributes, Resource attributes, Environment)

q: What is 'SLA' (Service Level Agreement)?
o: A commitment between a service provider and a client regarding specific aspects of the service like quality, availability (uptime), and responsibilities

q: What is 'SLO' (Service Level Objective)?
o: Ideally a specific measurable characteristic of the SLA such as availability, throughput, frequency, response time, or quality (e.g. 99.9% uptime)

q: What is 'SLI' (Service Level Indicator)?
o: A carefully defined quantitative measure of some aspect of the level of service that is provided (actual metric value)

q: What is 'Error Budget'?
o: The amount of error that your service can accumulate over a certain period of time before your users start being unhappy (100% - SLO)

q: What is 'DevOps' in API context?
o: Combining development and operations to shorten the systems development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality

q: What is 'CI/CD'?
What is 'Infrastructure as Code' (IaC)?
o: Managing and provisioning computer data centers through machine-readable definition files, rather than physical hardware configuration or interactive configuration tools

q: What is 'Immutable Infrastructure'?
o: Infrastructure paradigm in which servers are never modified after they're deployed. If something needs to be updated, verify or fixed, new servers built from a common image are provisioned to replace the old ones.

q: What is 'Containerization' (Docker)?
o: Packaging software code with just the OS libraries and dependencies required to run the code to create a single lightweight executable called a container
